post.content:
4️⃣4️⃣ Here's the 44th post highlighting key new features of the upcoming v258 release of systemd. #systemd258

Back in episode 10 of this series we talked about about the new "url-uki" stanza in boot loader spec type 1 entries, which configures UKIs that are placed on a remote URL rather than stored locally in ESP/XBOOTLDR. This story already hinted that UEFI HTTP network boot of UKIs is actually a thing now.

Back in episode 35 we talked about booting into a DDI root fs…

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

replies.content:
…downloaded via HTTP inside the initrd and placed into memory.

These two things complement each other nicely: the firmware downloads the UKI and transitions into it, and the initrd in the UKI then downloads the rootfs and transitions into that.

To make this really nice there's value in being able to derive the rootfs URL from the UKI url, so that both files can be placed on the same server, and only the first URL has the be declared in full.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content: To make this work systemd-stub learnt a new trick in v258: if it detects it is run as PE binary downloaded from HTTP, it will determine the source URL and then set the generic LoaderDeviceURL EFI variable to it. This EFI variable is part of the boot loader interface, and mirrors nicely the existing LoaderDevicePartUUID EFI variable that indicates the GPT partition UUID that the UKI was booted from. The former EFI variable hence is set for remote boots, the latter for local boots.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content:
bootctl has been updated to show the new variable. But more importantly, the systemd.pull= kernel cmdline switch we talked about in episode 35 knows the new "bootorigin" flag now. If used the URL to download an image from can just be a relative path, which is then combined with the UKI URL reported by systemd-stub, to form a full URL.

Example:

rd.systemd.pull=raw,machine,verify=no,blockdev,bootorigin:rootdisk:image.raw.xz root=/dev/disk/by-loop-ref/rootdisk.raw-part2

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content:
If such a switch is built into the command line of a UKI and that UKI is placed on a server http://example.com/foobar/uki.efi then this will result in the root disk being downloaded from http://example.com/foobar/image.raw.xz.

TLDR: it's now really nice to do UKI+DDI booting from UEFI HTTP.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content: @TriMoon @bluca https://github.com/systemd/particleos/pull/84

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

card.title: debian: drop debian-specific pam.d line from tmpfiles.d by bluca · Pull Request #84 · systemd/particleos
card.description:
On Debian there are custom patches that break /usr/lib/pam.d/ so login doesn't work:
Aug 28 17:52:55 particle-6579-bbfd login[1260]: PAM _pam_load_conf_file: unable to open config for /etc/pam....
card.image_description:
On Debian there are custom patches that break /usr/lib/pam.d/ so login doesn't work:

all_descendants.content:
@pid_eins Looking forward for such a UKI to kickstart a base #ParticleOS installer from which we can start an installation of a choosen distro...

I'm currently still unable to test ParticleOS due to the requirement of an initial local build.
This step could be done after the above on the installed system if done well IMHO...

The only thing we would need is an UEFI menu entry pointing to the Online UKI that kickstarts this all...

@bluca @pid_eins Thank you for working on that 👍

Are any of those images usable as-is from an USB at moment to get started with #ParticleOS?
If so could you write some documentation about the process wrt. which file to burn to USB to get what result in the README at https://github.com/systemd/particleos

I'm eager to test drive this 😉

all_descendants.content:
@bluca @pid_eins Excuse my noobiness but...

I still have no clue which raw image to try.
I tried downloading each `*_images/netesp_x86-64.raw.img` together with it's `.sha256` file, but the checksums don't match even after trying multiple times using `wget`.
```
$ shasum -c netesp_x86-64.raw.img.sha256
netesp_x86-64.raw.img: FAILED
shasum: WARNING: 1 computed checksum did NOT match
```

So i'm still unable to kickstart a fresh #ParticleOS installation to get started with this all 🤷‍♀️

all_descendants.content:
What i'm looking for as a fresh starter is something like this workflow:
1. Download a bootable image, Net-Install or Fixed-Distro-Variant, and put it on a USB.
2. Boot from the image and get prompted, via text or GUI, for disk to partition and install the #ParticleOS.
3. Ability to customize this install by building a new image from within this install which will be used to "update" the booted image.
This step includes adding new packages and a signing key for UEFI-SecureBoot

@bluca @pid_eins
Ahhh i didn't notice there were other pages in that listing, that's why i downloaded the netesp images 🤦‍♀️

Ok im now DL'ing the file you mentioned from the Debian_13_images dir, together with it's .sha256 file.
- Update: shasum went ok this time

Looking at the extension "zst" does this mean we need to uncompress the file using zstd before dd to USB? 🤔
- Update: Yep seems we need to unzstd the file first 👍

all_descendants.content:
@pid_eins
@bluca

Today I finally tried again, but whished I had not...

I KNOW it's my own FUCKING FAULT but argggg...

I have 2 NVME's in my system:
- NVME0 → Dedicated to test setups.
- NVME1 → My main working system.

Both with their own ESP's.
So far so good, all was working fine and I could boot each separately using the UEFI boot menu.

Until ofcourse i was DUMB enough to try #ParticleOS WITHOUT removing my NVME1, containing my main system, from my hardware before doing this test. 🤬

fields.name: Next Sosyal

fields.value: https://linux.social/@TriMoon

all_descendants.content:
@pid_eins
@bluca

Because it COMPLETELY WRECKED and reformatted both NVME's. 🤯
Even though I instructed to use only `/dev/nvme0n1`
And now I'm left with a PC without any working OS on it, because it didn't work anyhow...

Wish me strength to find energy to setup a new system *again* 🥵
#ParticleOS
